title: Global citizenship as a graduate attribute
abstractText:
A number of universities, most notably in Australia and Scotland, are growing their interest in the development of the graduate attribute of global citizenship.

This development is rarely accompanied by debate about the different ways in which this concept can be understood. Thus the overarching aim of this series is to address this inattention. We aim to generate a theorised direction for global citizenship as a graduate attribute and an underpinning pedagogic direction for its encouragement. We anticipate that these directions will be sufficiently expansive to grapple with the dynamic and complex interrelationship between social differences and commonalities among humans.
